body_str: Denault, J.

[Translation]: This is an application for judicial review of a decision by the Refugee Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board ("the Refugee Division") on August 27, 1998 dismissing the refugee status claim of the applicants, who are originally from Bangladesh.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>
The applicants feared persecution in Bangladesh because of the political and social activities of the principal claimant ("the claimant"). In March 1989 the claimant became a member of the
Jatiya Party Bhandaria Thana Branch of Pirojpur District
. He was elected a member of the executive committee in January 1993 and became treasurer in January 1994. The applicant was beaten twice by supporters of the
Bangladesh Nationalist Party

("BNP") when he was attending demonstrations. The latter attacked his business on one occasion and also vandalized his house. The applicant was also attacked twice by supporters of the fundamentalist organization
Jamaat-e-Islami
. The police arrested and beat the applicant on two occasions. On each occasion the applicant had to pay a bribe in order to be released.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

Relying on various omissions, contradictions and inconsistencies, the Refugee Division dismissed the testimony of the principal claimant, which appeared to them to be [TRANSLATION] "an entire fabrication". The panel also found the allegations of the claimant that he was active in the
Jatiya
Party to be less than credible. The applicant was even found to lack credibility on the fact that he belonged to a political party or had been sought by the Bangladeshi police.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

The applicants argued that the members of the Refugee Division made an error of law when they did not take into account a psychological expert opinion concluding that there was a severe post-traumatic stress disorder, and secondly, the specific documentary evidence of the applicant, namely letters setting out his social commitment regarding the oppression of women (P-8, p. 362 of the plaintiff's record), his membership in the
Jatiya

Party, in which he was even elected treasurer of one of the divisions (P-9, p. 364), and finally a letter from his counsel in Bangladesh describing his problems with the police (arrests, torture and bribes).  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>
The applicants further submitted that the Refugee Division also erred in concluding, first, that there was [TRANSLATION] "an absence of the minimum basis for these claims under s. 69.1(9.1) of the
Immigration Act
", and second, without providing any reasons for this conclusion.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

The respondent's response to the applicants' arguments comes down to the following proposition: assuming that the Refugee Division did not believe the principal applicant, it was not unreasonable to attach no evidentiary value to the psychological report and to conclude that there was an absence of minimum basis.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>
As I indicated at the close of the hearing of this matter, it is a case in which the court's intervention is warranted.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

In my opinion the panel was wrong to conclude that the principal claimant was not credible without taking into account and without discussing the content of the psychological report which found severe post-traumatic stress disorder and the applicant's difficulties relating the traumatizing events he had experienced, except for negatively arriving at the conclusion that these were facts he had not indicated in his personal information form.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>
The panel further erred in concluding that the principal claimant was not credible as to his political commitment to the
Jatiya

party and the fact that he was sought by the police, when independent evidence relating specifically to the applicant corroborated his testimony on this point. The panel did not say a word about this evidence, which not only corroborated important aspects of his claim but at the very least supported the credibility of his testimony. )See to the same effect
<FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  (T.D.).)  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

The application for judicial review is allowed. The matter is referred back to the Board for re-hearing and reconsideration by a panel of different members. The case raises no question of general importance.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>
Application allowed.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>
Editor: Angela E. McKay/saf  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>
